results.title: Welcome to Woop Woop
results.creator_credit: Scala Productions, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Unthank Films, Finola Dwyer and Stephan Elliott
results.brief_description:
Directed by Stephan Elliott, “Welcome to Woop Woop”, was the follow-up film after his smash hit “Priscilla, Queen of the desert”. A black comedy, the film is a satire on the great mythical Australian outback and the people that are said to inhabit it. The film is populated by unsavoury characters, who dress and act repulsively and speak in a crass and offensive dialogue, littered with ockerisms and bush slang. Teddy, a New York con artist flees America and goes on the lam in Australia. Once there is seduced by the sexually voracious Angie and taken to her hometown of Woop Woop where he is effectively imprisoned by the law of Daddy-O, Angie’s tyrannical father. Amongst other eccentric behaviours, the town folk gather nightly to watch “The Sound of music” and “South Pacific” played on a loop at the local drive-in. Elliot confounds viewer expectations offering up more extreme and vulgar outback personalities than could possibly be imagined, making these characters repugnant to watch. The film slyly sends up films such as “Crocodile Dundee” which pandered to the gross stereotypes that so appealed to audiences. Elliot however failed to appeal to anyone with this bizarre and subversive flick, receiving critical brickbats and woeful box office returns.
Cast includes: Johnathon Schaech, Rod Taylor, Susie Porter, Richard Moir, Maggie Kirkpatrick, Barry Humphries and Paul Mercurio

results.title: Welcome to the Waks family [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Documentary Films, SBS Independent, Barbara A. Chobocky and Rod Freedman
results.brief_description: Filmed over a period of five years, this fascinating documentary provides a rare insight into a Melbourne orthodox Jewish family, but not just any family, as the Waks family is probably the largest in Australia with 17 individual children to the same two parents. Zephaniah and his wife Chaya had their first eight children in Israel until they migrated to Melbourne in 1984 settling in East St Kilda, an area renowned for its Jewish community, schools and Synagogues. They follow the Lubavitch branch of Judaism which has many restrictions and strict daily laws and rituals including prayer three to four times a day, no visits to the cinema or theatre, no reading of novels, no listening or playing of popular mainstream music, no television except for educational or religious purposes and no mixing of boys and girls except within the family. Both parents expect their children to follow and practise these beliefs including finding a marriage partner through the “Matchmaker”. However, through the daily rituals, school, the on-going social and religious celebrations, no child is neglected or lacking in attention. There appears to be respect, love and a unity amongst the family members even in the most challenging of circumstances as shown by Zephaniah and Chaya in their patience and caring, and tolerance (even when hurt and disappointed) when one of their teenage sons turns away from his religion and joins the Israeli Army. Family is everything and compassion and compromise sometimes necessary to maintain the family unity. The Waks are not rich financially but they are rich where it matters in other aspects of life, particularly family and religion. An intriguing biographical documentary featuring archival footage, stills, location shots in New York, interviews with various members of the family and commentary by the filmmaker who is also a long time friend of Zephaniah’s.

results.title: Welcome to the dollhouse
results.brief_description: Todd Solondz’s debut feature is a darkly funny and bleak tale of the trials and horrors of high school outsiders. “Welcome to the Dollhouse” exacts with excruciating and all too familiar detail the ritualistic and cut throat pecking order of a New Jersey high school. In the title role Solondz has found an unusual alter ego in eleven year old Dawn Wiener (Heather Matarazzo), whose thick glasses, social awkwardness and infantile dress sense have marked her with the cruel nickname of Wiener dog. This has made her into the prime target for every high school bully including Brandon (Brendon Sexton the 3rd), a vicious delinquent who is constantly threatening to rape Dawn after school. Brandon’s promise of sexual assault become one of the many obstacles Dawn must deal with in her unrelenting journey through puberty, along with unsympathetic parents, a younger prissy sister that is unbearably wholesome, and a painful crush on the dreamy school rebel Steve (Eric Mabius). Cast also includes Daria Kalinina, Matthew Faber and Dimitri Iervolino. (Awards: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1996 Sundance Film Festival)

results.title: Welcome to Television (1956)
results.brief_description: Gyngell is often credited as being the first person to appear on Australian television on 16 September 1956, when he spoke the words, ‘Good evening, and welcome to television’.

constellations_other.name: Lost and found
constellations_other.description: Blossoming from Alice Guy Blaché’s The Cabbage-Patch Fairy, this Constellation explores the impermanence and enduring nature of the moving image.

results.title: Welcome to Sarajevo
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Television, Miramax Films, Graham Broadbent, Damian Jones and Michael Winterbottom
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a rare example of the war genre, one prepared to indict the western world for its refusal to aid the victims of a modern warzone like the former Yugoslavia. British journalist Michael Henderson (Stephen Dillane) begins a series of reports on a Muslim orphanage where dozens of children are trapped without food or medical support. His reports become pleas for help and finally scathing editorials before he takes matters into his own hands. Director Michael Winterbottom is careful not to paint Henderson as a hero, but rather the most ordinary of people forced to react against a heartless international community. With a cast that also includes Kerry Fox, Woody Harrelson and Marisa Tomei, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a different approach to the war genre - one in which no one involved is morally black or white.

results.title: Welcome to my nightmare
results.brief_description: A live on stage performance in England of Alice Cooper’s “Welcome to my nightmare” including some of his all-time classic songs “Only women bleed”, “Department of youth”, and “School’s out”. Alice Cooper is at his macabre best, sensuous and morbid in this elaborate rock production. Also features the voice of Vincent Price as the spider. Music conceived by Alice Cooper, Dick Wagner, Bob Ezrin and choreography by David Winters.

results.title: Welcome to Maffra
results.brief_description: This film starts with Darren McCubbin, the Mayor of the Wellington Shire, welcoming the audience to Maffra. Darren explains that we are about to visit some of the places and meet some of the people that make Maffra a unique place to live. The film features the Geoff Webster Centre, the Gippsland Vehicle Collection, the Maffra Gymnastics Club, the George Gray Centre, Wallaby Rise Restaurant, Cambrai Backpacker Hostel and Jenny McDavitt an Alpaca farmer and Ferial Zikerman who is now internationally known for her Maffra Cheese.

results.title: Welcome back, Norman
results.creator_credit: Film Communications, Mt Lemmon Production, Sharon Burke and Shevard Goldstein
results.brief_description: The comical character, Norman Krasner, is presented once again in this sequel of “Norman Krasner”. As a character who can turn common misfortune into near disaster, Norman depicts the weary businessman returning from a business trip. The setting is a busy airport’s parking lot. Norman turns the simple experience of getting out of the parking lot into a hilarious example of “Murphy’s Law”. Cast: Doug MacIntosh.

results.title: Weird science
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Joel Silver and John Hughes
results.brief_description: John Hughes wrote and and directed this teen farce. Gary and Wyatt are two unpopular geeks in high school who fantasise about having beautiful girlfriends and being the coolest kids in school. Inspired by a clip from the classic film “Frankenstein”, the two decide to try their luck at creating the woman of their dreams. The result is Lisa - beautiful, saucy and the answer to every man’s dream - who becomes a mentor to the two libidinous youths, her mission being to help them get the young women they want. Cast includes: Anthony Michael Hall, Kelly LeBrock, Ilan Mitchell-Smith, Robert Downey Jr. and Bill Paxton.
